case_name: Lokmanya Mills v. Municipality of Barsi

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 125 to 129 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 125 to 129 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and decree dated October 7, 1952 of Bombay High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 601 to 605 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 7, 1952, of the Bombay High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 601 to 605 of 1952.

facts.text: Lokmanya Mills are a company registered under the Indian Companies Act holding land City Survey No. 2554 within Municipal Borough with factory buildings, warehouses, bungalows and other structures.

anchor.surface_text: The Lokmanya Mills-hereinafter called the appellants-are a company registered under the Indian Companies Act holding an expensive area of land City Survey No. 2554 within the Municipal Borough on which are constructed buildings of the factory, ware-houses, bungalows and other structures appurtenant to the factory.

facts.text: Respondent is Municipality of Barsi constituted under Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, entitled to levy rate on lands and buildings and water-rate by s.73.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a Borough Municipality constituted under the Act is by s. 73, entitled to levy a rate on lands and buildings and also a water-rate.

facts.text: In 1944, Municipality resolved to enhance assessment of lands and buildings.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944, the Municipality resolved to enhance the assessment of lands and buildings within its area

facts.text: Municipality resolved rental value for levying rates on mills and factories at Rs. 40 for every 100 square feet after correspondence with Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: After some correspondence with the Commissioner, Central Division, the General Body of the Municipality resolved that the rental value for leaving rates on mills and factories within its limits be fixed at Rs. 40 for every 100 square feet.

facts.text: Notices under s.75b issued, objections invited, approved by Government of Bombay, new rules operative from April 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Notices of this resolution under s. 75 b  of the Act were issued and objections to the proposed enhancement were invited from the taxpayers and after obtaining the approval of the Government of Bombay, the new rules were made operative from April 1, 1947.

facts.text: Rule 2C: annual letting value for mills, factories and buildings relating thereto fixed at Rs. 40 per 100 square feet or part thereof for every floor, ground floor or cellar.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2C-As regards Mills, factories and buildings relating thereto, the annual letting value shall be fixed at Rs. 40 per 100 square feet or part thereof for every floor., ground floor or cellar and the tax shall be assessed on the said annual letting value, at the ordinary rate.

facts.text: Explanation to Rule 2C: buildings pertaining thereto include warehouses, godowns, shops of the mills etc. but does not include residential buildings like bungalows and out-houses.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation-The words buildings pertaining thereto include buildings in the compound of the Mills such as ware-houses, godowns, shops of the mills etc. but does not include residential buildings that is to say bungalows and out-houses.

facts.text: Municipality prepared assessment list under new scheme for factory buildings and issued notices of demand for house-tax and water-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality prepared an assessment list under the new scheme of taxation in respect of factory buildings and buildings relating thereto and issued notices of demand calling upon the appellants to pay house-tax and water-tax newly assessed thereon.

facts.text: Appellants paid tax under protest and filed five suits in Civil Judge, Junior Division of Barsi to recover excess over old scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants paid under protest the tax demanded, and filed five suits in the court of the, Civil Judge, Junior Division of Barsi to recover the amounts levied by the Municipality in excess of the amounts due under the old scheme.

facts.text: Principal issue in suits: validity of Rule 2C for levy of rates on mills, factories and related buildings.

anchor.surface_text: In all these suits, the principal issue raised was about the validity of rule 2C framed by the Municipality for levy of rates on Mills, Factories and other buildings relating thereto.

facts.text: Trial court (Civil Judge Junior Division Barsi) held Rule 2C valid and dismissed suits.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that rule 2C was valid and within the competence of the Municipality and dismissed the suits for refund of house-tax and water-tax.

facts.text: District Court at Sholapur in appeal declared Rule 2C illegal and ultra vires, restrained Municipality by injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court at Sholapur in appeal declared rule 2C illegal and ultra vires and by injunction restrained the Municipality from making any claim or demand for house-tax and other taxes from the appellants on the basis of the rule.

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside District Court decree, held Rule 2C not ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Judicature at Bombay, set aside the decree of the District Court disagreeing with the view that rule 2C was ultra vires.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Shah J. on March 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Prior to April 1, 1947, house-tax and water-tax levied on annual letting value at uniform rates for residential, business or manufacturing.

anchor.surface_text: Under the rules framed by the Municipality house-tax and water-tax were levied on buildings and non- agricultural lands on their annual letting value at uniform rates whether the purpose was residential, business or manufacturing.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Rule 2C not based on annual letting value, ignores statutory methods, renders objection right illusory, invalid.

anchor.surface_text: This was clearly not a tax based on the annual letting value, for Annual letting value postulates rent which a hypothetical tenant may reasonably be expected to pay for the building if let. ... The Municipality ignored both the methods of valuation and adopted a method not sanctioned by the Act.

facts.text: Appeals allowed, High Court decrees set aside, District Court decrees restored with costs.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals must be allowed and the decrees passed by the High Court set aside and the decrees passed by the District Court of Sholapur restored with costs in this court and the High Court.

facts.text: Annual letting value defined in s.3(1) as annual rent reasonably expected, including payments for taxes etc.

anchor.surface_text: The expression Annual letting value is defined in s. 3 1  of the Act as meaning the annual rent for which any building or land, exclusive of furniture or machinery contained or situate therein or thereon might reasonably be expected to let from year to year, and shall include all payments made or agreed to be made by a tenant to the owner of the building or land on account of occupation, taxes, insurance or other charges incidental to his tenancy.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 7, 1952, of the Bombay High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 601 to 605 of 1952.
the validity of Rule 2C framed by the respondent--the Municipality of Barsi under s. 58 j  of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925-hereinafter called the Act.

holdings.text: Rule 2C does not levy a tax based on the annual letting value as defined in the Act, since annual letting value postulates rent which a hypothetical tenant may reasonably be expected to pay.

anchor.surface_text: This was clearly not a tax based on the annual letting value, for Annual letting value postulates rent which a hypothetical tenant may reasonably be expected to pay for the building if let. ... The Municipality ignored both the methods of valuation and adopted a method not sanctioned by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory definition of annual letting value from s.3(1) requiring hypothetical tenant rent; Rule 2C uses floor area unrelated to this.

holdings.text: The Municipality ignored statutory methods of valuation (capital value or annual letting value) and adopted an arbitrary method based on floor area not sanctioned by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality ignored both the methods of valuation and adopted a method not sanctioned by the Act. By prescribing valuation computed on the area of the factory building, the Municipality not only fixed arbitrarily

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute permits only capital or annual letting value per ss.75,78; floor area method deviates without sanction.

holdings.text: Rule 2C renders the statutory right of the taxpayer to challenge the valuation illusory by fixing value arbitrarily on area rather than true valuation.

anchor.surface_text: By prescribing valuation computed on the area of the factory building, the Municipality not only fixed arbitrarily the annual letting value which bore no relation to the rental which a tenant may reasonably pay, but rendered the statutory right of the tax- payer to challenge the valuation illusory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objection under s.78 limited to area, not substantive valuation, violating procedural rights in ss.78-84.

holdings.text: The method adopted under Rule 2C is not a recognised method of valuation; tax would be valid if a recognised method were used.

anchor.surface_text: This case has in our judgement no relevance to the present case. If the Municipality of Barsi had adopted any of the recognised methods of valuation for assessing the annual letting value, the tax would not be open to challenge, but the method adopted was not a recognised method

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recognised methods are capital value or hypothetical rent; distinguishes Madras Railway as it used recognised method for open land.

holdings.text: The approach of assuming uniformity of return for factories and using flat floor area rate without evidence is not permissible under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this approach to a rating problem arising under the Act is not permissible. In any event, there is no evidence on the record of this case that the factories and buildings relating thereto such as ware-houses, godowns and shops of the Mills

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of uniformity across factories; deprives objection right; distinguishes Amalner case.
